results.title: Shoot the piano player = Tirez sur le pianiste [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Films de la Pleiade, Pierre Braunberger and Francois Truffaut
results.brief_description: After his deeply personal autobiographical debut, “The 400 Blows”, Truffaut’s second feature was a homage to film noir and gangster films. But unlike the strict genre rules of the Hollywood films, “Shoot the Piano Player” is as much a celebration of the pleasure and possibilities of cinema as it is a straightforward crime film. Peppered with comic asides, philosophical speculations, and dissertations on love, it is beautifully shot in black and white by Raoul Coutard and features a jazzy score by George Delerue (both cinematographer and composer were to have a longstanding collaboration with Truffaut). Based on a crime novel, “Down There” by David Goodis, the film stars Charles Aznavour who is convincingly seedy and attractive as a once famous classical pianist, Edouard Saroyan, who has abandoned fame and his career after the tragic death of his wife. His anonymity is shattered when his brother runs into him one night in a cafe. The brother is being pursued by two thugs who are after the loot Edouard’s older brothers have run off with after double-crossing the two thugs during a bank robbery. Wanting to protect his brothers, Edouard goes to their rescue, realising that it is his fate to have security, love and peace always snatched from him. On its release, “Shoot the Piano Player” cemented Truffaut’s reputation as one of the leading filmmakers in the French New Wave, the movement which was to influence and vitalise filmmakers across generations and across the globe. More humanistic and more playful than his groundbreaking colleague, Jean-Luc Godard, “Shoot the Piano Player” still astonishes with its wit, speed and irreverent spirit. Truffaut was to follow this film with “Jules et Jim” in 1961, ensuring that his first three films make for one of the most dazzling “adolescence” in movie history. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Shoot the nets
results.creator_credit: Cinetone Studios and Herman Van Der Horst
results.brief_description: Herring fishing in the North Sea, following a group of Dutch boats on a typical cruise. A documentary record of a Dutch trawler on its annual voyage to the Dogger Bank, fishing ground for herring. Shows the ceremonies and celebrations that usher in the herring fishing season, decking of boats with flags and departure of the fleet to the international fishing grounds. The nets are put out, the crew wake in the middle of the night for the laborious business of hauling in the catch, a storm comes up and the fleet turns home. The film stresses the cooperation at sea among fishermen of different nations who rely on the Dogger Bank for their livelihood.

results.title: Shonky golf with Mick Molloy
results.creator_credit: Radiant Industries, Stephen Luby, Emma Moss, Penelope Everett and Mick Molloy
results.brief_description: Mick Molloy, together with his coach and caddy, Alan Length, have compiled this instructional video about how to improve oneself at shonky golf. Together they cover areas such as the fundamentals (not just grip, but how to find a good parking spot in the carpark); getting the most out of the pro shop; navigating trouble spots; the mechanics of the golf cart; your relationship with the caddy, future directions in golfing attire, and most importantly, etiquette on the golf course. Put their advice into practice and you too can dubiously navigate your way around the green.

results.title: Shoeshine girl
results.creator_credit: MacDonald Productions, Jane Startz and Peter Barton
results.brief_description: Story of a problem girl who goes to stay with her aunt during the summer vacation and the relationship she forms with the shoeshine man who hires her as his assistant. Raises issues concerning cooperation with others, and respect for the individual differences and beliefs of others.

results.title: Shocked
results.creator_credit: Danielle Karalus and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: Shocked takes takes you on a psychological journey with Jessica and you are asked to determine her future. Jessica’s perfect perfect world crumbles after the birth of her first child. The increasing pace and often chaotic nature of the interface and soundscape matches the chaotic world that Jessica inhabits. Shocked; game-like in its interactivity, is so real it makes you question your own values, and is so compelling you won’t be able to stop.

results.title: Shock to the system
results.creator_credit: Corsair Pictures, Patrick McCormick and Jan Egleson
results.brief_description: Graham Marshall (Michael Caine) is a middle-aged New York advertising exec recently passed over in a sure fire promotion to a younger subordinate (Peter Riegert). Suffering the effects of this crushing oversight, Graham inadvertently pushes a panhandler into the oncoming path of a subway train, killing the man instantly. Charged with murder, Graham is released on manslaughter. This leads him to speculate on the possibility of repeating his actions - murder, camouflaged as accident - and plots to get back at some of his enemies, starting at home with his shrewish wife (Swoosie Kurtz). The downtrodden suit has turned into a likeable avenger. This parable of corporate greed in post 1980s Wall Street is a curious mix of thriller and black comedy. Cast also includes Will Patton as the obligatory gumshoe and Elizabeth McGovern as the sympathetic co-worker and love interest. Based on the novel by Simon Brett.

results.title: Shock corridor
results.creator_credit: Allied Artists Pictures and Samuel Fuller
results.brief_description: Peter Breck plays an ambitious reporter, Johnny Barrett, who decides to imitate an insane psychiatric patient in order to write an expose on conditions in a psychiatric asylum where a murder has recently been committed. He finds himself losing the grip on his own sanity when he confronts his fellow inmates who all exhibit paranoiac and delusional fantasies. Before long Johnny is no more sane than any of the other men inside. Samuel Fuller’s intense thriller is a searing and truly frightening dissection of American social malaise. Johnny’s fellow inmates all exhibit schizophrenic and psychotic behaviour that is reflective of the social divisions in their contemporary culture. A black man, so psychically disfigured by racism, believes himself to be a white man in the Ku Klux Klan; a man thinks he is a Civil War General because he can not deal with the stigma of being branded a “Commie”. Within the limitations of a B-movie budget, Fuller has created one of the finest and most caustic metaphors for the damage inflicted on the national psyche by the Cold War and the orgy of witch-hunts initiated by the McCarthy-era blacklist.
